Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2008 09:39AM dcissurvivor wrote: I am very new to this topic of bone mets......and will be honest in that I don't really understand what this is but it is scaring me.  I had a bilateral mastectomy in May of 2006.  Last week I found a lump under my left armpit which I am getting checked out next week.  For the last year or so I have been experiencing alot of back pain which I have been assuming is osteo arthritis - I am 48 yrs young.  Sometimes the pain is in more than just my lower back - upper back, hips, shoulders and neck.  I have felt under the weather like I'm coming down with something, but never really get anything, for the last 3 to 4 months. I wonder if I should ask my doctor next week about getting a bone scan? Thoughts?
Posts.Title: PET Scan vs, Bone Scan JoyRebecca nuclear1

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 11:04AM dcissurvivor wrote: Hi Susan, Thank you for your response.  I had a total hysterectomy 10 years ago and in 2006 had a bi-lateral mastectomy.  I am BRCA1 positive and thought I was in the clear because I no longer have ovaries or breasts - then I read an article on Primary Peritoneal Cancer.  Apparently people that are BRCA1+ have a higher risk of getting this type of cancer even if they have no ovaries.  This is because PPC is a rare cancer that starts in the Peritoneum.  Peritoneum is the membrane that lines the inside of the abdomen. The lining of the abdomen and the surface of the ovary come from the same tissue when we develop from embryos in the womb. PPC is a cancer that starts in this tissue. I beat breast cancer but I have many other cancers in my family (stomach, pancreatic, hodgkins lymphoma, brain, eye, cervical) so I guess I am a tad paranoid.  I am going to request a CA125 blood test once a year.  This test checks the levels of protein called CA125.  Levels of this can be higher than normal of PPC is present.  Anyway, thanks for listening and responding.  Take care and have a great day.  Regards, Linda.
Posts.Title: Peritoneal Cancer dcissurvivor dcissurvivor

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 09:21PM dcissurvivor wrote: Jeanette, I waited six months from my bilateral before having the expanders put in.  After the initial bilateral surgery I swore I would not wilingly go under the knife ever again especially for cosmetic reasons......after a couple months I changed my mind and am very happy with my choice.  What I'm saying is that you do not have to decide right away and it's best to wait a few months before reconstruction anyway rather than having immediate recon.
Posts.Title: Confused: Reconstruction or NOT?? jeanette51 Sparkle2
